title: Rotten Ralph
text:
Rotten Ralph is a <a href="book%20series">series</a> of <a href="children%27s%20literature">children's</a> <a href="picture%20books">picture books</a> written by <a href="Jack%20Gantos">Jack Gantos</a> and illustrated by <a href="Nicole%20Rubel">Nicole Rubel</a>. About twenty "Rotten Ralph" books have been published from 1976 to 2011. 
"Rotten Ralph" is also the first book in the series, a 32-page picture book published by <a href="Houghton%20Mifflin">Houghton Mifflin</a> of Boston in 1976. It was the first published book for both Gantos and Rubel.
Alternatively, Rotten Ralph is the title character of the series, initially "a very very nasty cat" —a bright red <a href="domestic%20cat">domestic cat</a> who enjoys playing mean, <a href="practical%20joke">practical joke</a>s on his human family.
There was a <a href="children%27s%20television%20series">children's television series</a> by <a href="Cosgrove%20Hall%20Films">Cosgrove Hall Films</a>, <a href="Tooncan">Tooncan Productions</a> and <a href="Italtoons%20Corporation">Italtoons Corporation</a> based on the books, first broadcast on <a href="CBBC%20%28TV%20channel%29">CBBC</a> from 1998 to 2001. It also went to air on <a href="Nickelodeon%20%28UK%20and%20Ireland%29">Nickelodeon</a> in the UK too, around 2000. The show hasn't been aired in the UK since reruns ended in 2005. The show aired in the United States on the <a href="The%20Family%20Channel%20%28American%20TV%20network%2C%20founded%201990%29">Family Channel</a> in 1999–2001.
Books.
All of the "Rotten Ralph" books have been written by Jack Gantos and illustrated by Nicole Rubel.
This list of nineteen titles with publishers and publication dates is compiled from U.S. national library and <a href="WorldCat">WorldCat</a> library catalog records.
According to a "Horn Book Magazine" review of "The Nine Lives of Rotten Ralph" in May 2009, the series had previously comprised "eight picture books (plus four early readers). This ninth volume flashes back to those marvelous stories and the unbridled antics therein, which, unfortunately for Ralph, shaved off eight of his lives." Eight Rotten Ralph books had then been published by Houghton Mifflin, all picture books; "Nine Lives" was the ninth. Four "rotten readers" had been published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux.
